text: hello everyone today I'm going to
demonstrate how AWS fraud control
takeover protection supports inspection
of origin
response AWS W is a web application
firewall that helps protect web
applications from attacks by allowing
you to configure rules that allow block
or monitor web request based on
conditions that you define AWS W is
multi-layered security service that can
protect against a wide range of security
threats it is a fully managed service
which means the resources needed for
your enabled controls will be
provisioned
automatically you can use AWS manage
rules covering common threats or
configure your own customized rules it
is highly flexible rule engine that can
inspect incoming request with single
digit millisecond
latency
AWS WF is tightly integrated with all
these AWS Services AWS customers
commonly use to deliver content for
their websites and
applications when you use AWS W on
Amazon cloudfront your rules run in all
AWS Edge locations located around the
world close to your end users this
account takeover protection for
inspection of origin responses is
currently available only for cloudfront
distributions account takeover is an
online illegal activity in which an
attacker gains unauthorized access to a
person's account the attacker might do
this in a number of ways such as using
stolen credentials or guessing the
victim's password through a series of
attempts you can monitor and control
account takeover attempts by
implementing the AWS wav fraud control
account takeover pre
prevention this manag rule inspects
login request against an updated
database of leaked credentials from
previous breaches and also looks for
abnormally High rates of login request
indicating a Brute Force login attack
AWS W offers this feature in the AWS
managed rules rule group AWS managed
rules ATP rule set and companion
application Integrations sdks
ATP manage rules can now also inspect
application response data and Block
login attempts based on customer defined
login failure conditions this capability
helps to protect against Brute Force
attacks involving non-compromised
credentials for login path uh you will
provide the path of the login endpoint
for your application you also have to
specify how your application accepts
login attempts by providing the request
payload type and the names of the fields
within the request body where the
username and password are provided your
specification of the field names depends
on the payload
Tye please note this is a paid AWS
managed rules and there is a monthly
subscription charge of $10 per month and
based on the request let's see how you
can create webcl with this feature let's
move on to AWS console and let's select
W and shield
service we can see web SEO tab on the
left let's create one web ACL for
account takeover
prevention please make sure the region
is global since this feature is only
available for cloudfront distributions
and cloudfront is a global
service let's click on create
web we will pick a name
AWS
wav
ATP let's make sure the resource type is
Amazon cloudfront
distributions under web request body
inspection we will leave it as a default
then under Associated AWS resources this

manage tool
groups here we can see account takeover

to edit the required configuration let's
click on
edit here we can configure ATP as we can

enter the path of your login group uh I
will just for an example I'll just put
SL paath
login you can then select the payload

and we will enter the names of the
fields within the request body where the
username and password are
provided you can specify success or
failure conditions based on HTTP status
codes HTTP headers or the body of the
responses as well as Json strings I will
use status code for component type and
will include ATP to inspect responses
that include the HTTP Response Code 200
for Success condition and
401 for failure condition scrolling
further down here is all the account
takeover prevention rules and we can see
the two
failed login response as volumetric
failed login response high and
volumetric session fail login response
high so volumetric faade login response
High inspects for IP addresses that have
recently been the source of too high a
rate of failed login attempts a high
volume is more than 10 failed logins
request from an IP address in a 10minute
window this rule applies the rule action
and labeling to new web request from an
IP address based on the success and
failure responses from the protected
resource to recent login attempts from
the same IP address you define how to
count successes and failures when you
configure the rule group similarly
volumetric session fail login response
High inspects for client sessions that
have recently been the source of too
high a rate of failed login attempts our
high volume is more than 10 fail login
requests from a client session in a 30
minute window this rule applies the rule
action and labeling to new web requests
from a client session based on the
success and failure responses from the
protected resource to recent login
attempts from the same client session
you define how to count successes and
failures when you configure the rule
group as you can see the rule group uh
rule action is block but you can
override to other options to allow count
cap
or challenge again please remember awaf
only evaluates this rule in web ACLS
that protect Amazon cloudfront
distributions then let's click on Save
rules let's click on ADD
rules here we can see the AWS manage
rules rule group AWS manage rules ATP
rule set let's click next
this is where you can set rule priority
if you have multiple
